It's a wide, astonishing world out there, and we're all in it.  Does anyone out there find it's helpful to see a shrink? I've tried shrinks and haven't had much luck.

Posts.Title: How do people deal with the fear? Lesley1 mthomp2020

Posts.Content: Lesley1 wrote: I'm having some bone pain tonight and I'm just blanketed by fear, so I thought I'd post. They just found cancer in two new places--the cervix and in the parotid area of my face--there's a small tumor you can't even see above my jaw. My doctor's been EXTREMELY reassuring about this latest turn--says, "you're not dying of breast cancer," "you will continue to do well," "the biology of your cancer is at the extreme end of the spectrum"--meaning, you have a kind that is extremely slow growing. I've had this for nearly 20 years now. All the same, tonight I'm REALLY scared. What do people tell themselves to get through the fear? What kind of things do you do to help yourself?  Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: How do people deal with the fear? Lesley1 mthomp2020

Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2008 09:11AM Lesley1 wrote: Jesus. Okay. Let's all do our best to make ourselves heard. I'd like to start by trying to write something about this for the Huffington Post. I'd love to hear from/talk to people here on the subject. For instance, Jo-Ann K, your story's really powerful--it so strongly illustrates the reality of what's going on. But I'm not sure: am I allowed to post an interview request on here? How do I go about trying to contact people for this? Can I post my email address and ask people to write me? I don't want to violate any rules, so if someone knows proper procedures to follow, please let me know. Thanks!!
Posts.Title: Cancer Funding Has Flatlined?! Lesley1 ihatesnowihatesnow

Posts.Content: Lesley1 wrote: Have people been following this story? Funds for new research for cancer treatements by the NIH is drying up? There was so much going on before, and now it's stalled. Apparently, there's a recession on here, too.   Everybody, check this out: http://www.alternet.org/healthwellness/102539/medical_research_recession:_funding_flatlined_for_diabetes,_cancer,_alzheimer's_/  I know I'm alive right now because there was a bump in the number of treatments a while back. I bet a lot of other people on here are too. To h*ll with pink ribbons and the sense that the October pink splurge gives the country that we're blazing forward with cancer research. We're not. I have a question for everyone: what can we do? Any suggestions? Is there some protest that, together, we can lodge?  A march on Washington?  I really really wish that Barack O'bama's mother hadn't died of cancer, but perhaps that fact would make him amenable to this problem. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Cancer Funding Has Flatlined?! Lesley1 ihatesnowihatesnow

Posts.Content: Lesley1 wrote: I recently read that there's been some evidence that Zoloft may interfere with  Tamoxifen. Does anyone know if the same holds for Zoloft and all the hormonals? I started on Aromasin six weeks ago; three weeks ago, I went on Zoloft. Now I'm wondering if I should get off the Aromasin? But it's been so nice not to be in perpetual silent dread. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Zoloft interferes with all hormonals? Lesley1 saluki

Posts.Content: Lesley1 wrote: Has anyone else heard of this? My cancer's been largely confined to the bones, but lately it showed up just above my jaw: not in the bone, but under the skin (not skin mets: in the tissue). I look a little like I'm getting the mumps on that side. Two and a half months, my doctor switched me to Aromasin. I've been really responsive to hormonals, so we're hoping that works. I have to say, though, it doesn't look any smaller.  This is such a weird place to have metastases. Just putting this out there to ask what people think. Thanks. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Face mets??? Lesley1 beastybabe

Posts.Content: May 3, 2008 06:27PM Lesley1 wrote: They confirmed it with a fine needle aspiration. Mets to the face area like this is such a rare occurence, three doctors--including my oncologist--said, "That's not cancer" when I showed it to them. They all thought it was a blocked salivary gland or a begnign tumor, but all urged me to get someone else to look at it.
Posts.Title: Face mets??? Lesley1 beastybabe

Posts.Content: Nov 2, 2009 05:53AM Lesley1 wrote: This video (link below) has been helping me with this stuff lately. It's of the Canadian Indian actress Lisa Ray, an otherworldly beauty, who was diagnosed last July at 37 with incurable cancer--multiple myeloma, to be exact, but she's in the same boat we are. She was immediately put on some kind of steroid treatment and the weight piled on; she's got the steroid moon face. And now, because she has a film coming out, she has to get out there and promote a movie she made before all this happened, when she was still lithe and a world class-beauty. She's by no means ugly now, but she's not the same. And just watch how she handles it in this video. That's her on the right in the film clip at the beginning and then that's her now talking, and she just doesn't seem cowed by this. She seems sparkling and unbeaten and unapologetic, and every time I look at this, I take strength from it. It can't be easy to have been called one of the ten most beautiful women in the world last year, and to have the press now saying, "The glamor is gone" (someone wrote that about her weight gain), and yet, she just gets out there and doesn't hunch down embarrassed.  www.youtube.com/watch?v=aKxAQJ...
